profileText: A Representative from Maryland; born near Oaklands in Anne Arundel County, Md., in 1778; attended St. John's College, Annapolis, Md.; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice; major in the Maryland Militia 1812-1818; elected as an Adams candidate to the Nineteenth and Twentieth Congresses, and reelected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-first Congress (March 4, 1825-March 3, 1831); resumed the practice of law; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1832 to the Twenty-third Congress; judge of the fifth circuit court of Maryland until his death in Leonardtown, St. Mary's County, Md., August 6, 1848; interment in a private burial ground at ``Summerseat,'' near Laurel Grove, Md.

researchRecord.name: In the Robert Goodloe Harper Papers, 1796-1823, 50 items.
ca. 1814, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Clement Dorsey to the governor of Maryland, written around 1814, regarding the arming of state soldiers.

recordLocation.name: Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: 1834, 3 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Clement Dorsey to Daniel Webster written on January 10, 1834. In the letter, Clement Dorsey relates a conversation about General Jackson and the United States Bank and notes that Mr. Clay's effort for the Bank was too forensic. Clement Dorsey also tells Daniel Webster that he should not debate John C. Calhoun on the "Force Bill."
